text: General elections were held in Cambodia on 11 September 1966.Dieter Nohlen, Florian Grotz & Christof Hartmann (2001) Elections in Asia: A data handbook, Volume II, p63 Only candidates of the Sangkum party were allowed to contest the election, although more than one candidate could run in a constituency. As a result, the party won all 82 seats.Nohlen et al., p74 The conservative wing of the Sangkum gained a majority. On 18 October the National Assembly of Cambodia nominated Lon Nol as Prime Minister. ==Results== Only 28 of the 82 deputies had been previously elected to Parliament, six of whom were members of the conservative wing of the Sangkum. {| class=wikitable style=text- align:right |colspan=9|300px |- !colspan=4|Party !Votes !% !Seats !+/– |- |rowspan=2 bgcolor=#f8a102| ||rowspan=2 align=left|Sangkum||bgcolor=#010066| ||align=left|Conservatives|| || ||59|| |- |bgcolor=#f8a102| ||align=left|Sihanoukist|| || ||23|| |- |align=left colspan=4|Total|| || ||82||+5 |- |align=left colspan=8| Source: Nohlen et al. |} ==Government formation== The conservative wing of the Sangkum won a two-thirds majority in parliament, meaning Sihanouk could not prevent the opposition from blocking nominations. As a result, Lon Nol was elected Prime Minister with 59 votes in favour and 23 against. ==References== Cambodia Category:Elections in Cambodia Category:1966 in Cambodia Category:One-party elections
title: 1966 Cambodian general election
